document.masterDocTitle: A catalogue of Nolidae Bruand, 1846 from India (Lepidoptera, Noctuoidea)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A catalogue of Nolidae Bruand, 1846 from India (Lepidoptera, Noctuoidea)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Beaninae , a monogeneric subfamily, is represented by single species of the genus
Beana
in India . The adults are robust, noctuid-like in wing-shape; pattern is restricted to the forewing, which is irregularly variegated, mostly brown, with an apical patch defined by an arcuate section of the submarginal line and a central, irregularly arcuate fascia running from the costa at two-fifths to near the tornus on the posterior margin, which may define paler patches on their concave sides; the hindwing is with M 3 and CuA 1 connate only. The male genitalia have a somewhat triangular uncus, which is laterally rather convex at base and tapering to an acute apex that may be modified into a setose, sometimes bifid pad; most species bear a distinctive pair of ‘‘elbowed’’ scaphial processes associated with the anal tube; valves are often with complex processes at apex of sacculus and a small spine arising from interior of the costa near its apex ( Zahiri & Holloway 2013 ).

Type species:
Beana polychroma Walker, 1862

Chloephorinae was recognized as a member of the family Nolidae by Holloway (2003) . For
Chloephorinae,
Zahiri et al. (2013)
suggested a synapomorphic character of raised, lobed tympanal sclerite (an orange-brown bar) in the middle of the accessory tympanum that projects into the ear and appears to slightly overlap the tympanal membrane. The subfamily as a whole contains all the genera with tymbal organs developed on the basal abdominal sternite in males.
Zahiri et al. (2013)
recognized six well supported tribes:
Ariolicini, Careini, Chloephorini, Eariadini, Gelastocerini and Sarrothripini. Kononenko & Pinratana (2013)
also included Camptolomini in Chloephorinae . Reporting of
Pseudoips fagana Fabricius
by
Sanyal et al . (2018)
,
Tathothripa arcuosa Bethune-Baker
by
Das et al . (2020)
and
Erizada rufa Hampson
by
Joshi et al . (2021)
from India needs further investigation. This is the largest subfamily represented by 180 species under 52 genera in India .

The Eligminae share a derived forewing shape, which is rather elongated and narrow, especially in
Eligma
,
Iscadia
,
Elaeognatha
and
Baroa
. The adult labial palpi are unusually long and porrect, and are often slightly flattened laterally. Ocelli are present and the tibial spur formula is 0–2–4. The frons lacks a tubercle. In most genera, the retinaculum is finger-like except
Iscadia aperta Walker. In
male genitalia, the uncus is bifid in genus
Baroa
, reduced or absent in
Iscadia
and related genera, and long, strongly developed and well sclerotized in other members like
Elaeognatha
( Holloway 2003 ;
Zahiri et al . 2013
). This subfamily is known by 23 species under 09 genera from India .

Nolinae are mostly small sized moths, with forewings variegated by black, grey and white, with areas of raised scales; male antennae may be filiform, ciliate or bipectinate; ocelli are poorly developed or absent; male abdomen lacks tymbal organs but usually has apodemes on the eighth tergite. The male genitalia have a simple uncus (fully reduced in
Nola
) and simple valves with a characteristically ‘noctuid’ saccular harpe; many genera have a pair of setose lobes that flank the scaphial area of the anal tube; aedeagus can have apical projections, and the vesica may contain cornuti. The female genitalia have the ovipositor lobes (Papilla anales) usually short, quadrate or, seen together, rather conical; dusctus bursae is often slender, elongate; corpus bursae is usually pyriform or ovoid, generally with a pair of signa or scobinate corrugations ( Holloway 2003 ). This subfamily is known by 105 species under 24 genera from India (
Joshi et al. 2019
, 2020, 2020a) with four new records to India :
Casminola seminigra ( Hampson, 1896 )
,
Evonima ronkaygabori Han & Hu, 2019
,
Meganola suffusata
( Wileman & West, 1929 ) and
Nola euryzonata ( Hampson, 1900 )
.
